Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Silica-Based Materials with Improved Biocompatibility
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RUI award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to San Jose State University is to develop new silica materials of high biocompatibility, as defined by low protein adsorption onto the surface and by enhanced protein structure and stability when encapsulated in the glass matrix. A key hypothesis behind this project is that biocompatible materials must have a proper balance of hydrophilic and hydrophobic surface groups and that this balance should be similar to the surface of a folded protein. Hydrophilic charged and uncharged groups, and hydrophobic functional groups will be incorporated into the silica matrix to disrupt the interfacial water layer and to examine the relationship between surface chemistry and protein structure. In working toward the specific aims, the results of this project may yield: (1) improved silica-based materials for application in the biosensor industry, (2) insights on how to reduce protein adsorption for materials used in making implants and other biomedical devices, and (3) a better understanding of protein behavior in crowded and confined environments, as relevant to the biochemistry of living cells. Undergraduate students will be trained to make organically-modified silica glasses using the sol'gel technique and to analyze the structure of encapsulated or adsorbed proteins by circular dichroism spectroscopy.


Protein molecules are designed by nature to function in a highly crowded environment, yet most experiments for characterizing proteins are performed in dilute solutions. This project aims to study model proteins in a crowded and confined environment made from silica glass. More specifically, this project will modify the silica surface with various chemicals to make the environment more protein-friendly (biocompatible), as measured by changes in the protein structure upon entrapment in, or adsorption to, the modified glasses. This work will be completed by undergraduate research students, including several minority students supported by other research programs. Also, a local high school teacher will be recruited during each summer to train and work side-by-side with the students. This summer internship is envisioned as a means of re-invigorating the teacher's passion for science and, at the same time, as a means of introducing undergraduate students to a role model who has chosen an important, alternative career path. Possible scientific impacts of this project include improved silica-based materials for application in the biosensor industry, insights on how to reduce protein adsorption for materials used in making biomedical devices, and a better understanding of protein behavior in its naturally-crowded environment.

Daryl K. Eggers, PI, San José State University

Outcomes Related to Intellectual Merit

The general goal of this project was to develop and test new porous glass materials made from silica in an effort to find conditions where a protein can be immobilized within the silica material and still maintain its biological function. Because protein function depends directly on achieving the correct protein structure (i.e., folding to the correct 3-dimensional shape), this project relied greatly on a special technique known as CD spectroscopy to monitor changes in the protein structure as a function of the different compositions of silica. Very few laboratories in the world have used this technique to study protein structure in solid materials, partly due to the fact that the material must be optically transparent for CD spectroscopy to be used for analysis; thus, silica glass is an ideal material for this work.

Model proteins were purchased from commercial sources and trapped in silica glasses that were made at room temperature in a two-step process known as the sol–gel technique. The silica composition was modified with various reagents to introduce new chemical properties in the pores of the silica and to determine if certain groups enhanced the structure of the protein (i.e., made the silica more biocompatible). Many chemical modifications were tested, including reagents that changed the water-binding properties of the silica surface. In general, many silica modifications were found to influence protein structure. One key result, that was not anticipated, is the fact that the most favorable changes in silica composition occurred at very low additions of the modifying reagent. In other words, “more” isn’t always better when working with proteins in modified silica glasses.

Outcomes Related to Broader Impacts

The results of this work are expected to impact many other fields and products by leading to (1) improved silica-based materials for the biosensor industry which often involve the use of immobilized proteins, (2) insights on how to alter the biocompatibility of implants and other biomedical devices that contact human tissues, and (3) a better understanding of protein behavior in crowded and confined environments, as relevant to understanding the function of proteins in living cells.

The training and educational aspects of this project cannot be overstated. All of the experiments were completed by undergraduate students, and several of these students have used their research experience as a stepping stone to the next career goal, including medical school, graduate school, and jobs in the biotech industry. One of the former researchers landed a prestigious NSF fellowship after starting a PhD program at the University of Wisconsin. Furthermore, this project funded a summer internship for three different high school science teachers. Each of the teachers was very enthusiastic about their summer experience, and, in each case, their high productivity in the laboratory exceeded the expectations of the principle investigator.
